title.native: 宮本武蔵 -双剣に馳せる夢-
title.romaji: Miyamoto Musashi: Souken ni Haseru Yume
title.english: Musashi: The Dream of the Last Samurai

description:
A chronicle of the life of legendary swordsman Miyamoto Musashi.

Musashi, a name familiar to many, a legendary swordsman who has become one of Japan's greatest mythical and historical heroes. In addition to writing one of they texts of Japanese samurai tactics and philosophy, "The Book of Five Rings," he is also famous for inventing the Ni-Ten Ichi Ryuu style of two-sword fighting, perhaps the most obvious, recognised visual trademark of the samurai today. But even with so much academic study dedicated to Musashi's life, books, movies, anime and manga stories inspired by his legendary exploits and teachings, still questions remain unanswered. Musashi: The Dream of the Last Samurai attempts to answer one of these in particular - what motivated the great warrior to adopt and perfect his dual bladed style?

(Source: Manga Entertainment)

node.description:
[Twitter](https://twitter.com/oshii_mamoru)

An anime and live-action director, mostly known for the former, whose seminal titles include [Urusei Yatsura 2: Beautiful Dreamer](https://anilist.co/anime/1921/), [Angel's Egg](https://anilist.co/anime/885/), the first two [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) films and the [Ghost in the Shell](https://anilist.co/anime/43/) films, as well as the Kerberos Saga universe of which [Jin-Roh](https://anilist.co/anime/570/) is a part.

His affinity for Euro arthouse cinema, his falling out with the Christian religion, and his fascination with the unsuccessful anti-occupation, pro-communist protest movement in postwar Japan shaped his unusual sensibilities. Recurring themes and aesthetics in his works include oppressive police states, unsuccessful protest movements, dysfunctional bureaucracies, political action that results in stasis, biblical scripture, and imagery, philosophical dilemmas, characters trapped in seemingly inescapable situations, the use of dialog as descriptive "texture" rather than a plot-driver, and otherwise Euro-arthouse pacing and storyboarding. He is both polarizing to mainstream audiences, and highly revered by cinephiles and Hollywood directors; his works have influenced Hollywood films such as Dark City, The Matrix, and Avatar.

[Kenji Kamiyama](https://anilist.co/staff/100348/), an anime director also closely associated with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/), is his protégé.

Aspired to become an animator simply because he wanted to draw for a living. Later enrolled to and graduated from Tokyo Animator Gakuin. He then joined [Magic Bus](https://anilist.co/studio/207/) and debuted as an in-betweener in 1987 under the studio's name on [God Bless Dancougar](https://anilist.co/anime/5266/). Nakazawa soon left Magic Bus and went freelance. In 1993, he was involved in the establishment of Studio G-1, an animation studio founded by [Masami Oobari](https://anilist.co/staff/100660/). During his time there he participated in many of [AIC](https://anilist.co/studio/48/)'s productions. Nakazawa got strongly influenced by Oobari during this time due to working under him on multiple occasions. Also unlike most animators at the time, Nakazawa wasn't really that shaped by [Yoshinori Kanada](https://anilist.co/staff/106398/)'s style, he was though, a huge fan of [Ichirou Itano](https://anilist.co/staff/103268/)'s and [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/)'s.

In 2002, Nakazawa made his directorial debut with Comedy, part of an anthology titled [Sweat Punch](https://anilist.co/anime/1072/), produced by [Studio 4°C](https://anilist.co/studio/13/). The following year he directed both [Parasite Dolls](https://anilist.co/anime/1350/) jointly with [Naoyuki Yoshinaga](https://anilist.co/staff/115038/), as well as the animated part in Quentin Tarantino's movie, Kill Bill: Volume 1. This brought him a lot of international praise. He then got reached out to by director [Shinichirou Watanabe](https://anilist.co/staff/97009/) of [Cowboy Bebop](https://anilist.co/anime/1/) fame, about the possiblity of taking part in the director's next work, [Samurai Champloo](https://anilist.co/anime/205/). Nakazawa accepted the offer and ended up being a crucial part of its production, handling the character designs and serving as the sole chief animation director on the show. He also directed, storyboarded and wrote the 15th episode. Ten years later in 2014, Nakazawa collaborated with Watanabe for the second time on [Terror in Resonance](https://anilist.co/anime/20661/), providing the character designs and working as an animation director on the series.

In recent years he has been closely involved with [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/鶴岡陽太)

Founder and representative director of [Rakuonsha](https://anilist.co/studio/211/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/西久保瑞穂)

Husband of late voice actress [Yuuko Mizutani](https://anilist.co/staff/95485/).

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1522114648098619397)

He grew up admiring anime such as [Space Battleship Yamato](https://anilist.co/anime/1650/) an during highschool he started animating with his friends. He enrolled into a professional animation school after graduating but quit quickly due to being disappointed in how the lessons were conducted.

He joined Anime R and later its subsidiary Studio Muu. His first work was as an in-betweener on [Psycho Armor Govarian](https://anilist.co/anime/6428/) while his debut as a key animator was on [Captain Tsubasa](https://anilist.co/anime/2116/).

After working on [Mamoru Oshii](https://anilist.co/staff/99097/)'s [Patlabor](https://anilist.co/anime/1095/) he permanently joined Production I.G. becoming known, together with [Hiroyuki Okiura](https://anilist.co/staff/103502/) and [Tetsuya Nishio](https://anilist.co/staff/103725/), as "The Three Gods of I.G."

He's is one of the most prominent animators of the realist school, with emphasis on solid shapes and weighty character animation.

Kouji Komurakata is a director, storyboard artist, and animator formerly affiliated with [Ajiado](https://anilist.co/studio/30/Ajiado). He currently heads Animation Department of [Production I.G](https://anilist.co/studio/10/Production-IG) Studio Niigata.
Took part as a key animator on Quentin Tarantino's "Kill Bill: Vol. 1" in 2003.

Affiliated with [Ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/).

Famous for Directing and Storyboarding the Iconic Episode 19 of [Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba](https://anilist.co/anime/101922/Demon-Slayer-Kimetsu-no-Yaiba/).

Initially, he did not want to become a director, but when he served as the animation director for episode 3 of [Fate/Zero Season 2](https://anilist.co/anime/11741/FateZero-Season-2/), "The Terminus of Honor,'' he became interested in the direction of [Takashi Suhara](https://anilist.co/staff/146678/Takashi-Suhara), a director affiliated with [ufotable](https://anilist.co/studio/43/ufotable). [In Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works](https://anilist.co/anime/19603/Fatestay-night-Unlimited-Blade-Works/), Shirai not only made his debut as a storyboard and director for TV anime but also contributed to the art design.

According to ufotable's representative director and president, [Hikaru Kondou](https://anilist.co/staff/103076/Hikaru-Kondou), he mentioned that Toshiyuki Shirai is a staff member who, despite being young, can be entrusted with crucial story elements and scenes . [In Fate/stay night: Unlimited Blade Works 2nd Season](https://anilist.co/anime/20792/Fatestay-night-Unlimited-Blade-Works-2nd-Season/), Shirai took In charge of the storyboard and direction for the final decisive battle in episode 12, titled "Unlimited Blade Works." The original creator, [Kinoko Nasu](https://anilist.co/staff/98250/Kinoko-Nasu), highly praised Shirai, stating, "It's craftsmanship to the extreme. You did a splendid job".

In [Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba](https://anilist.co/anime/101922/Demon-Slayer-Kimetsu-no-Yaiba/), Shirai handled the storyboard, direction, and layout for episode 19, titled "Hinokami." The original creator, [Koyoharu Gotouge](https://anilist.co/staff/119973/Koyoharu-Gotouge), expressed admiration, saying, "The animation, direction, music, everything is so amazing that I cried a lot and watched episode 19 about 20 times. I'm truly glad I worked so hard on the manga." This episode received high acclaim not only from Japanese viewers but also internationally. 

Specializing in action-oriented direction, Toshiyuki Shirai made his Series directorial debut with [Katsugeki TOUKEN RANBU](https://anilist.co/anime/21742/Katsugeki-TOUKEN-RANBU/) in 2017.
